threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered ransomware. Other contributing factors were that it has known exploits and it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert ( gid:116; sid:58; rev:2; msg:"(tcp) experimental TCP options found"; metadata: policy max-detect-ips drop, rule-type decode; classtype:protocol-command-decode;)

attributes.magic: ELF 64-bit LSB executable, x86-64, version 1 (SYSV), dynamically linked, interpreter /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2, for GNU/Linux 2.6.18, BuildID[sha1]=f22530d02604a1030e6fab308464ae8ab9c5f817, stripped

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis: This binary is a specialized Linux ransomware variant known as 'Monti', specifically designed to target VMware ESXi environments. It implements a multi-stage destructive workflow: it uses 'esxcli' to list and kill running virtual machines, overwrites system files like '/etc/motd' and VMware web interface files ('index.html') with a ransom note, and recursively encrypts files in user-specified paths using RSA-2048 and AES. It includes anti-analysis features such as a '--detach' flag to run as a daemon. Key IOCs include the hardcoded RSA public key, references to 'MONTI: ESXI ransomware S-klass', the creation of 'vm-list-temporary.txt', and ransom-related .onion URLs.
